review.title: Self-organized control for musculoskeletal robots
review.abstract: With the accelerated development of robot technologies, optimal control becomes one of the central themes of research. In traditional approaches, the controller, by its internal functionality, finds appropriate actions on the basis of the history of sensor values, guided by the goals, intentions, objectives, learning schemes, and so on planted into it. The idea is that the controller controls the world---the body plus its environment---as reliably as possible. This paper advocates for a new paradigm of control, obtained by making the world control its controller in the first place. The paper presents a solution with a controller that is devoid of any functionalities of its own, given by a fixed, explicit and context-free function of the recent history of the sensor values. When applying this controller to a muscle-tendon driven arm-shoulder system from the Myorobotics toolkit, we observe a vast variety of self-organized behavior patterns: when left alone, the arm realizes pseudo-random sequences of different poses but one can also manipulate the system into definite motion patterns. But most interestingly, after attaching an object, the controller gets in a functional resonance with the object's internal dynamics: when given a half-filled bottle, the system spontaneously starts shaking the bottle so that maximum response from the dynamics of the water is being generated. After attaching a pendulum to the arm, the controller drives the pendulum into a circular mode. In this way, the robot discovers affordances of objects its body is interacting with. We also discuss perspectives for using this controller paradigm for intention driven behavior generation.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: The controller defined above was used in the experiments with a tendon-driven arm-shoulder system from the Myorobotics toolkit [15], see Fig. 1. The system has 11 artificial muscles, 8 in the shoulder and 2 in the elbow and one that affects both. However, two of the shoulder muscles have been uncoupled. The muscles consist of a motor that pulls a tendon connected to a spring, see Fig. 1 (b). The length of a tendon l is specified by the motor encoders and the spring force is translated into a length s in the interval [− α, 1 − α], where α defines the pretension (here α = 0.1). The length of the tendons is normalized to l [− 1, 1]. We define the sensor values asxi = li + ßsi (5), where β regulates the integration of the spring length. In the experiments β was simply set to 1 without further adjustment. This choice is not expected to be critical.

sections.heading: 3.1 Peculiarities of muscle-tendon driven systems
sections.text: There are a number of features that distinguish the musculoskeletal tendon-driven systems (MTD) from the classical robots, which have rotary joints with direct motor control, i.e. the motor positions translate directly into joint angles and poses. The most obvious effect is when the tendons weaken, causing total loss of contact with the physical condition of the arm. This must be avoided by maintaining a permanent tension on the tendons, which is another problem: the tension can only be achieved by tightening each tendon against all the others, with each individual tension being reported by the length of the spring. This means that (i) there are infinite combinations of tensile forces for one arm and (ii) that the effect of a single motor is reflected in a change in the spring length of all the other muscles. In other words, the operation of a single muscle is reflected by a pattern of sensory stimulation - a whole-body combination that generates friction and multiple muscle combinations.

sections.heading: 3.2 Self-regulation, manipulability, and goal orientation
sections.text: We performed several experiments listed in Tab. 1, which show the main characteristics of the control scheme. All experiments are performed with the same controller with the same initialization (C = 0), so that only the physical situation differs between the experiments. We will keep this work mainly at the level of the phenomena and provide a more in-depth analysis in a later essay. We recommend using the videos for a better understanding.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Self-regulated working regime
sections.text: Before presenting the experiments in detail, let's take a look at the sensorimotor coupling generated by this controller. One of the key features is the self-regulation into a working regime in which the tendons are kept under tension even during very fast movements under considerable stress. This is very important as it guarantees that the signals from the controller are clearly executed. As a result, in all experiments we have never had to deal with a shoulder dislocation, see Figure 1 (c), which can occur immediately when the tendons come loose. This is all the more surprising as this meaningful work regime arises without any additional adjustment or calibration of the system [34]. For this, the special sensor configuration equivalent (5) seems to be important, but we have not yet systematically studied it and expect other configurations to work.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Manipulability
sections.text: The dominance of the sensor reactions in the control system makes the controlled system manipulable by externally applied forces. The point is that all additional forces acting on the arm segments change the sensor values due to the changing spring stress. This effect integrates manipulative influences - such as a physical robot interaction - into the sensor values and thus into the metsystem in which it relaxes when the mechanical degrees of freedom are manually frozen. This is not because the motors are too weak. Instead, x-0 is a fixed point of dynamics that succeeds in freezing the mechanical degrees of freedom. Furthermore, the system can be drawn into specific behaviors through manual interaction. We demonstrate this in the handshake experiment, see video 2, where the user tries to move the arm in a periodic pattern.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Perspectives for goal oriented behavior
sections.text: The idea is based on the observation that the metsystem (the physical system with the controller that regulates the energy input) exhibits completely different physical characteristics from the "naked" or passive system (the motor power is turned off). Specifically, the self-amplification is dampened by a second controller acting on the metsystem - let's call it the meta-controller - so that the meta-system enters a plastic state of aggregation. In this particular regime, patterns are present as mere potentials waiting to be aroused. It is easy to imagine that by a second controller - let's call it the meta-controller - acting on the meta-system, it is more reliable to propel the meta system toward these latent behaviors than by acting on the "naked" physical system. If we are able to manipulate the meta system by hand, why not simply by imposing additional motor signals on the self-regulated system a meta meta system system that resembles the one above?

sections.heading: 3.3 Emerging modes
sections.text: As mentioned above, the meta-system with the transition operator L т is particularly similar to periodic movements, i.e. there is a plethora of latent boundary cycle attractors waiting metaphorically for their excitation. In other words, the selection of a specific attractor is realized by the self-amplification of a dynamic seed that is generically provided by a physical subsystem (the world) with a temporally coherent internal dynamics. In other words, the subsystem - through its internal dynamics - steers the meta system into a resonant state, i.e. an integral system mode with a defined frequency. This prominent phenomenon is a direct consequence of the fact that the world is assigned the leading role in behavior generation. In the following experiments, we feed additional delayed sensor values that enhance the affinity to periodic behaviors, see Section 5.3.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 Self-excited pendulum modes
sections.text: In a first experiment, we set a weight (the bottle) from the tip of the arm. In this experiment, the world consists of the arm together with a physical subsystem - this pendulum - with a complex internal dynamics. However, with the pivot point at rest, the pendulum can realize elliptical or even circular motion patterns with fixed frequency. By a driven pivot point, the pendulum is able to realize chaotic movements under certain trajectories of the pivot point. In any case, the movements of the weight exert small forces on the arm, which change the spring stresses and thus the sensor values.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 The emerging cocktail shaker
sections.text: In the next phase, we will get a bottle of water into the bottle, both in horizontal and vertical orientation. These experiments should support our hypothesis that the water touches either the walls or the bottom of the bottle.

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Discovering object affordances and tool use
sections.text: The observed resonance phenomena are closely related to the concept of affordability of objects. As Gibson [7] introduced, affordability is a means of action available to an individual in the environment. Depending on the capacity to act, affordability defines the relationship between an agent and his environment through his motor and sensory abilities (e.g. tangible, movable or edible). In this sense, we can say that the metsystem discovers the possibility of pushing the pendulum pendulum pendulum into a circular motion by moving the pivot point in a certain way. In this sense, it is an affordability that a pendulum can offer in this specific environment. Interestingly, this discovery can only be achieved through the emerging activity of the entire system with the pendulum based on the very weak interactions in the arm-pendulum physical system. In the same sense, if we give the robot the half-filled bottle, through which (by the inertia of the forces) of the water system already provide a wheel with possible actions.

sections.heading: 3.4 Reaching
sections.text: The functionality of the current control paradigm is essentially based on two different scenarios. On the one hand, we have observed a strong affinity for periodic movements such as the pendulum or bottle shaking methods, which are predominantly associated with time scales defined by ρ to the expected periodicity. There, we observe that the dynamic operator L с is essentially constant and qualified by (a pair) complex eigenvalues that determine the frequency of oscillations. In other time horizons, which are either shorter or do not correspond to the periodicity of a latent mode, we observed another amazing variety of behavior patterns that give the impression that the robot intentionally creates sequences of different poses, see video 7. This scenario is characterized by an L ² that varies strongly on the time scale of the behavior itself. Although these motion sequences look rather random, it is important to note that it is not artificial randomness that the controller is planted.

metadata.abstractText: With the accelerated development of robot technologies, optimal control becomes one of the central themes of research. In traditional approaches, the controller, by its internal functionality, finds appropriate actions on the basis of the history of sensor values, guided by the goals, intentions, objectives, learning schemes, and so on planted into it. The idea is that the controller controls the world—the body plus its environment—as reliably as possible. However, in elastically actuated robots this approach faces severe difficulties. This paper advocates for a new paradigm of self-organized control. The paper presents a solution with a controller that is devoid of any functionalities of its own, given by a fixed, explicit and context-free function of the recent history of the sensor values. When applying this controller to a muscletendon driven arm-shoulder system from the Myorobotics toolkit, we observe a vast variety of self-organized behavior patterns: when left alone, the arm realizes pseudo-random sequences of different poses but one can also manipulate the system into definite motion patterns. But most interestingly, after attaching an object, the controller gets in a functional resonance with the object’s internal dynamics: when given a half-filled bottle, the system spontaneously starts shaking the bottle so that maximum response from the dynamics of the water is being generated. After attaching a pendulum to the arm, the controller drives the pendulum into a circular mode. In this way, the robot discovers dynamical affordances of objects its body is interacting with. We also discuss perspectives for using this controller paradigm for intention driven behavior generation.
